1118430297790398464.text: Thiel: It will be more localized. To get our current account deficit back to zero probably requires a set of policies that would be labeled as very anti globalist. I'm in favor of them.

1118430297211592704.text: Thiel: It still has a long ways to go. And so I would say, again. One way we get to a healthy financial system would be that we have no current account deficits than the banks will have less money, they'll have less power over the economy.

1118430296632750080.text: Thiel: The biggest current account deficits we had were in 06-07 at the peak of the housing bubble, $800B/year current account deficit. The way that gets sterilized is that you have banks telling foreign investors $800B worth of lies on why they should put the money to subprime.

1118430296066498560.text: Thiel: In 1987 banks are doing really well. '91 it was down to zero. 2000 SNLs go broke. Mike Milken goes to jail. That's what happens when the current account deficit comes down. The money runs out for banks.

1118430295517097984.text: Thiel: The other countries aren't buying goods or services, but they're sending us money back. The money that gets sent back get sent back to the banks. And so the bigger the current account deficit, the more money flows into the banks.

1118430294887915520.text: Thiel: Then the mirror image of that is a chart that reflects the dollars that flow into the US so we’re sending money out in the current account deficit.

1118430294351024128.text: Thiel: If you plot on x axis time, y axis the current account deficit. It was zero in 1980, it went down to -3.5% of GDP in 1987, back to zero in 1991. And then it went by '06-'07 down to 6% or 7% of GDP. And then in '08 we’re on -3%. Just picture the chart.

1118430293679935489.text: Thiel: It’s not the local banks, it’s not even the national banks. It’s these crazy global capital flows that direct it. You can think of the banking system in the US as the mirror image of the current account deficit.

1118430293063417856.text: Thiel: Why did it get to be so extreme in 2007? The simplified answer I would have is globalization because globalization is what makes things the most disconnected.

1118430292354539520.text: Thiel:  And the business model of Manhattan consists of people producing little pieces of paper that say "you owe me money and we need that." We don’t. it shouldn’t be as big a part of the economy as it is. And the historical question is, why did it get to be big?

1118430291645751297.text:
Thiel: The most disconnected you can get is in a purely globalized world. 

I often think the way to think of Manhattan in the United States is the financial center. The way you should think of it pictorially is it’s like an island. It’s really 1000 miles off the coast of the US.

1118425708089368576.text: Thiel: The peak of over-financialization was 2007 when half the profits in the US were made by banks or other financial firms. What % of the profits in the capitalist system should be made by a financial entities? My intuition would be 10%-15% is healthy. 50% is way too much.

1118424409125949441.text: Thiel on the SF Housing Crisis: "When it’s $2,000 for a 1BR apartment in 2011 in San Francisco, that’s what you have in a gold rush town. Comes with the territory. Is this the team to keep it in the bottle? Conscientious, agile, good to each other, get things done
